parts.text: The diagram shows two forces acting on an object: 6 N to the right and 2 N to the left. What is the resultant force?
markScheme: Answer: C – The resultant force is 6 − 2 = 4 N to the right

parts.text: The diagram shows the forces acting on a BASE jumper. Complete the sentences using words from the box.
segments: A BASE jumper accelerates forwards when force A is
force B. The BASE jumper falls at constant speed when force C is

parts.text: The graph shows how the velocity of a car changes with time. Complete the sentence using words from the box.
segments: From B to C the car moves at constant velocity. The forward driving force is

parts.text: What word is used to describe the motion of an object that is slowing down?
How is velocity different from speed?

questions.title: Newton's third law and typical speeds
questions.subject: physics

parts.text: The diagram shows an athlete on starting blocks. Complete the sentence using words from the box.
segments: The force from the athlete pushing backwards on the starting blocks is
the force from the starting blocks pushing forwards on the athlete.

parts.text: What is the average running speed of a typical person?
markScheme: Answer: B – The typical running speed of a person is approximately 3.0 m/s

parts.text: An athlete runs 100 m in 12.5 s. Calculate the average speed.
A BASE jumper opens a parachute. What effect does opening the parachute have on the speed of the falling BASE jumper? Give a reason for your answer.
markScheme: 1 mark: Opening the parachute increases **air resistance** / drag (or parachute has a large surface area)

parts.text: A ball and the Earth form a system. What is meant by 'a system'?
options: A group of objects that interact
Objects with big differences in mass
markScheme: Answer: A – A system is a group of objects that interact

parts.text: Figure 1 shows a distance-time graph for an athlete from the moment the race starts. Three parts of the distance-time graph are labelled J, K and L. Match each label to the correct description of the athlete's motion for that part of the graph.
What distance does the athlete travel after the end of the race before stopping?

questions.title: Distance-time graph for a dog walk
questions.subject: physics

parts.text: Figure 1 shows how the distance from home changes with time during a dog walk. Which part of the graph, A, B, C or D, shows them walking the fastest?
parts.explanationPrompt: Give a reason for your answer.
markScheme: 1 mark: The gradient/slope is the **steepest** (answers must be comparative)

parts.text: Calculate the weight of water when the mass is 25 000 kg. Gravitational field strength = 9.8 N/kg.
The weight of the water is 1 960 000 N and the bottom area is 49 m$^2$. Calculate the pressure at the bottom.

There is a force acting on the side of the swimming pool because of the water pressure. Figure 1 shows the side of the swimming pool. Which arrow shows the direction of the force acting on the side of the swimming pool?
markScheme: Answer: B – The force due to water pressure acts horizontally outwards (perpendicular to the surface)

parts.text: A child swimming at 0.70 m/s accelerates for 5.0 s to reach 1.3 m/s. Calculate the acceleration.
Which is the unit for acceleration?
markScheme: Answer: C – The unit for acceleration is m/s²

parts.text: Complete the sentence using words from the box.
segments: The velocity of the athlete is the
of the athlete in a given direction.

parts.text: Suggest two changes that could be made to the design of an electric go-kart to increase its top speed.
markScheme: 1 mark: Make the shape/body more **streamlined** (or lower the seating position)
1 mark: **Increase** the power of the engine, or **reduce** the mass/weight of the go-kart

parts.text: A go-kart travels at 13 m/s. The total mass of the go-kart and driver is 140 kg. Calculate the momentum.
Figure 1 shows the velocity-time graph for a go-kart during the first 40 seconds of a race. Between which two points did the go-kart have the greatest acceleration?
parts.explanationPrompt: Give a reason for your answer.
markScheme: 1 mark: The gradient/slope is the **steepest** (steeper than the other sections)

parts.text: Write the equation that links acceleration, mass and resultant force.
A cyclist and bicycle have total mass 80 kg and accelerate at 1.2 m/s². Calculate the resultant force.
A trolley has forces of 2.7 N to the right and 1.5 N to the left. The trolley has a mass of 0.75 kg. Calculate the acceleration.

Figure 1 shows the velocity-time graph for a car driven along a straight road. Between A and B the car is accelerating. Calculate the acceleration of the car between A and B. From the graph: at A the velocity is 0 m/s and at B (6 seconds) the velocity is 18 m/s.

A diagram shows horizontal forces acting on a moving motorbike. Force A acts backwards (resistive force) and force B acts forwards (driving force). Describe the movement of the motorbike when force A equals force B.
markScheme: 1 mark: In a **straight line** (accept any reference to direction; 'constant velocity' scores both marks)

parts.text: What happens to the speed of the motorbike if force B (driving force) becomes smaller than force A (resistive force)?
Write down the equation that links acceleration, change in velocity and time taken.
Figure 1 shows how the velocity of a motorbike changes when it is travelling along a straight road. What was the change in velocity of the motorbike in the first 5 seconds?
Calculate the acceleration of the motorbike during the first 5 seconds. The change in velocity is 20 m/s over 5 seconds.
An athlete is at the start of a race along a straight track. In the first 2 seconds, the athlete accelerates constantly and reaches a speed of 9 m/s. Calculate the acceleration of the athlete.
The graph shows how the stopping distance of a car depends on speed. Describe what happens to the stopping distance when the speed doubles.
A car is travelling on an icy road. Describe and explain what might happen when the brakes are applied.
markScheme: 1 mark: The vehicle may **skid** / slide (or loss of control / brakes lock)
1 mark: Due to reduced **friction** between tyres and road

parts.text: Name three factors, other than weather conditions, that would increase the overall stopping distance of a vehicle.
markScheme: 1 mark: Slower driver **reactions** (e.g. tiredness, alcohol, drugs, distraction)
1 mark: Poor vehicle maintenance (e.g. worn **brakes** / worn **tyres**) or increased mass

parts.text: Write the equation that links extension, force and spring constant.
The force on a spring is 336 N and the extension is 0.21 m. Calculate the spring constant.
The original length of the spring is 0.84 m. When a child stands on it, the length decreases by 0.21 m. Calculate the percentage change in length.
Figure 1 shows how the velocity of a cyclist changes with time. Complete the following sentence: The velocity includes both the speed and the __________ of the cyclist.
Why has the data for the cyclist been shown as a line graph instead of a bar chart?
markScheme: 1 mark: Velocity and time are both **continuous** variables (not categoric)

parts.text: The diagrams show the horizontal forces acting on the cyclist at three different speeds. The length of an arrow represents the size of the force. Which one of the diagrams, A, B or C, represents the forces acting when the cyclist is travelling at a constant 9 m/s?
parts.explanationPrompt: Explain the reason for your choice.
markScheme: 1 mark: The velocity is not changing / speed is **constant** (accept not accelerating / not decelerating)
1 mark: The forces must be **balanced** / equal (or the resultant force is **zero**)

parts.text: Figure 1 shows the maximum impact force for three different makes of running shoe (A, B and C) used on three different types of surface. Which one of the three makes of running shoe, A, B or C, has the best cushioning system?
parts.explanationPrompt: Explain the reason for your answer.

parts.text: The data needed to draw the bar chart was obtained using a robotic athlete fitted with electronic sensors. Why is this data likely to be more reliable than data obtained using human athletes?
markScheme: 1 mark: The conditions can be **repeated** exactly (or difficult to measure forces with human athletes, or human athletes may have different weights/speeds)

parts.text: Two students investigated how the acceleration of a trolley depends on the force applied. Student A hypothesised: 'The acceleration of the trolley is directly proportional to the force applied.' Predict what would happen to the acceleration of the trolley if the force applied to the trolley is doubled.
Student B hypothesised: 'Changing the force applied to the trolley will change the acceleration of the trolley.' Why is it difficult to make a valid prediction using the hypothesis of student B?
markScheme: 1 mark: The hypothesis does not say **how** increasing/decreasing the force increases/decreases the acceleration (it does not specify the relationship)

parts.text: Figure 1 shows some of the equipment used by the students (a trolley on a sloping runway). Write a list of any other equipment the students will need to complete the investigation.
markScheme: 1 mark: Appropriate equipment to apply and measure force (e.g. **newton meter** or slotted masses + string + pulley)
1 mark: Appropriate equipment to measure change in velocity and time (e.g. **ticker timer** + tape or **light gates** + datalogger)

parts.text: Why should the students use a sloping runway?
options: To reduce the effect of friction on the trolley.
To decrease the acceleration of the trolley.
To stop the trolley rolling back up the runway.
markScheme: Answer: A – To reduce the effect of friction on the trolley

parts.text: Describe a method the students could have used for their investigation.
markScheme: 1 mark: Describe a method by which the trolley is to be **accelerated** (e.g. using hanging masses on a string over a pulley)
1 mark: Describe how the accelerating **force is varied** to give a suitable range of results
1 mark: Describe how the accelerating force is **measured**
1 mark: Use suitable apparatus to measure the change in **velocity** of the trolley over a given distance or time
1 mark: Describe what **data** is to be collected in order to calculate acceleration
1 mark: Describe how the data required is to be **measured**
1 mark: Include an appropriate number of **repeat** readings
1 mark: Describe an appropriate range of forces and a sensible number of **data points**

parts.text: The students used the same trolley throughout the investigation. Suggest why.
markScheme: 1 mark: So that the **mass** is constant (a control variable)
1 mark: As changing mass would change the acceleration produced by a given force (or so there is only one **independent variable**)

parts.text: Figure 2 shows the students' results plotted on a graph of acceleration against force. Explain why hypothesis A ('acceleration is directly proportional to force') gives a better explanation of the results.
markScheme: 1 mark: The results give a **straight line** that passes through the **origin**
1 mark: Showing **direct proportionality** (between acceleration and force)

parts.text: Figure 1 shows the distance-time graph for part of a bus journey. How far has the bus travelled in the first 20 seconds?
Describe the motion of the bus between 20 seconds and 30 seconds.
Describe the motion of the bus between 30 seconds and 60 seconds.
markScheme: Answer: A – The bus is accelerating (the gradient of the distance-time graph is increasing)

parts.text: A trolley is attached to two identical springs. When the trolley is pushed and released, a wave travels along an elastic cord fixed to the trolley. What type of wave travels along the cord?
Give the reason why this type of wave is produced along the cord.
markScheme: 1 mark: The oscillation/vibration is **perpendicular** to the direction of energy transfer / wave travel

parts.text: Suggest one change that could be made to the apparatus to produce a wave with a lower frequency.
markScheme: 1 mark: Use springs with a **smaller spring constant** (weaker springs) or use a trolley with **greater mass**

parts.text: A parachutist has a mass of 75 kg. Calculate the weight. (g = 10 N/kg)
A bus is moving and has 500 000 J of kinetic energy. The brakes are applied and the bus stops. How much work is needed to stop the bus?
A bus has 500 000 J of kinetic energy and stops in 25 m. Calculate the braking force.
What happens to the kinetic energy of the bus as it is braking?
markScheme: 1 mark: Kinetic energy is transferred by **heating**

parts.text: A ball is dropped, hits the ground and bounces. Figure 1 shows the velocity-time graph for the ball from when the ball is dropped until when the ball reaches the top of its first bounce. Air resistance has been ignored. Describe the motion of the ball between points A and B on the graph.
markScheme: 1 mark: The acceleration is **uniform** / constant / steady

parts.text: What direction is the ball moving between points C and D on the graph?
When the ball hits the ground, energy is transferred from the ball to the Earth. Explain how the data in the graph shows this energy transfer.
markScheme: 1 mark: Velocity just after bounce is **less than** velocity just before bounce
1 mark: So the ball has **lost energy**
1 mark: The ball has lost **kinetic energy** (or has reduced gravitational potential energy at top of bounce)
1 mark: Total energy of ball and Earth system is **conserved** / constant

parts.text: A car driver sees a dog on the road ahead and has to make an emergency stop. Figure 1 shows how the speed of the car changes with time after the driver first sees the dog. Which part of the graph represents the 'reaction time' or 'thinking time' of the driver?
What is the thinking time of the driver?
The thinking time is 0.7 s and the car travels at 24 m/s. Calculate the thinking distance.
The car decelerates from 24 m/s to 0 in 4 s after braking. Calculate the acceleration.
Calculate the distance travelled by the car during braking. The car decelerates from 24 m/s to 0 m/s over 4 seconds.
markScheme: 1 mark: Correct substitution: $d = \frac{24 + 0}{2} \times 4$ (or area under graph = $\frac{1}{2} \times 24 \times 4$)

parts.text: The car has mass 800 kg and decelerates at 6 m/s². Calculate the braking force.

Figure 1 shows the forces acting on a parachutist in free fall. Figure 2 shows how the vertical velocity of the parachutist changes from the moment the parachutist jumps from the aircraft until landing on the ground. Using the idea of forces, explain why the parachutist reaches a terminal velocity and why opening the parachute reduces the terminal velocity.
markScheme: 1 mark: On leaving the plane the only force acting is **weight** (downwards)
1 mark: As the parachutist falls, **air resistance** acts upwards
1 mark: Weight is greater than air resistance, so the **resultant force** is downwards
1 mark: As velocity/speed increases so does **air resistance**
1 mark: Terminal velocity is reached when air resistance equals **weight** (forces are balanced)
1 mark: Opening the parachute increases **surface area**
1 mark: This increases air resistance so it is **greater than** weight
1 mark: The resultant force acts **upwards** / opposite to motion, so the parachutist decelerates
1 mark: The lower velocity means reduced air resistance until forces **balance** again at a lower terminal velocity

parts.text: A student tested model parachutes A, B and C (different sizes, made from one large plastic bag). The student dropped each parachute from the same height and timed how long each took to fall. The height was a control variable. Name one other control variable in this experiment.
markScheme: 1 mark: **Mass** of the modelling clay (or material parachute is made from, or number/length of strings)

parts.text: The student's hypothesis is: 'The larger the area of a parachute, the slower a parachutist falls.' Use the hypothesis to predict which parachute, A, B or C, will hit the ground first.
parts.explanationPrompt: Give a reason for your answer.
markScheme: 1 mark: C has the **smallest** area so falls **fastest** (taking the least time)

parts.text: A child steps off a diving board. Initial velocity = 0 m/s, acceleration = 9.8 m/s², distance fallen = 0.95 m. Using $v^2 = u^2 + 2as$, calculate the final velocity to 2 significant figures.
markScheme: 1 mark: Final answer: **4.3 m/s** (to 2 significant figures)

parts.text: Explain why the data for a cyclist has been shown as a line graph instead of a bar chart.
markScheme: 1 mark: Both velocity and time are **continuous** variables (not categoric)
